hints.content: Let's think about each statement to see whether it is true.

###The shaded numbers are all odd.

These shaded numbers are odd:

$1, 19, 37, 55, 73, 91$

These shaded numbers are even:

$10, 28, 46, 64, 82, 100$

This statement is *not* true.

###To get to the next shaded number, add $10$, then subtract $1$.

$\begin{align}
1\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 11 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}10\\\\
10\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 20 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}19\\\\
19\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 29 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}28\\\\
28\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 38 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}37\\\\
37\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 47 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}46\\\\
46\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 56 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}55\\\\
55\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 65 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}64\\\\
64\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 74 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}73\\\\
73\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 83 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}82\\\\
82\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 92 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}91\\\\
91\goldE{+10 - 1} &= 101 - 1 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=}100
\end{align}$

This statement is true.

###There are never two shaded numbers in the same row.

The shaded numbers $1$ and $10$ are in the same row.

This statement is *not* true.

This statement is true:

- To get to the next shaded number, add $10$, then subtract $1$.

question.content:
**Which statement describes a pattern in the shaded parts of the hundred chart?**

![hundred chart with 1, 10, 19, 28, 37, 46, 55, 64, 73, 82, 91, and 100 shaded](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/4ff05751e3ef4e7e21e72a473a83293c453f3051)

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: The shaded numbers are all odd.
To get to the next shaded number, add $10$, then subtract $1$.
There are never two shaded numbers in the same row.
